module.p: sin that (one) is a demonstrative pronoun, identifying an entity based on its spatial location proximal to the hearer.
sin contrasts with seo this (one) (proximal to the speaker) and siud that (one) over there (proximal to neither speaker nor hearer).

section.p:
sin can be used as the subject of a verb –
Tha sin cudromach. That is important.
Cha tèid sin fodha. That (one) will not go down.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha sin blasta. | Tha sin glè mhath. | Tha sin glan. | A bheil sin comhfhurtail?
That is tasty. | That is very good. | That’s nice. | Is that comfortable? td. 27, 195, 19

When sin is used as the subject of the copula is, the copula itself is usually dropped –
Is sin Dòmhnall. ⇒ Sin Dòmhnall. That is Donald.

Pedagogical examples –
Sin an tidsear. | Sin an cat. | Sin an sgian. | Sin a’ bheinn ud a-rithist.
That is the teacher. | That is the cat. | That is the knife. | That is yon mountain again. td. 27–8, 195

Examples with dummy subject pronouns –
pedagogical examples –
Is e sin Iain.
That is John. td. 27
negative examples –
Chan e sin Iain.
That is not John. td. 27

sin can be used as the object of a verb –
Chunnaic mi sin a-rithist. I saw that (one) again.

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through diligence, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5 (dèan) sin refers to a recently described event.

sin can be used as the complement of a preposition –
Thàinig iad le sin. They came with that (one).

sin can be used as the specifier of a noun –
Tha mi a’ faicinn sin. I can see that (one).
Tha e ri taobh sin. It is beside that (one).

sin can serve as a modifier of the definite article, appearing after the specified noun and any attributive adjectives –
am balach beag sin that little boy
na craobhan àrda sin those tall trees

Pedagogical examples –
singular –
an taigh sin | a’ bhùth sin | a’ bheinn mhòr àrd sin
that house | that shop | that big high mountain td. 26, 195
plural –
na dealbhannan sin
those pictures td. 26

sin can modify a third-person personal pronoun, thus yielding explicitly gendered or plural demonstratives –
e sin that [masc.]
i sin that [fem.]
iad sin those

module.p: an·sin there, at that place is the demonstrative adverb derived from sin.

Pedagogical examples –
Tha an cat an sin.
The cat is there. td. 28

Adnominal examples –
am boireannach sin an sin
that woman there td. 195
